channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Land Mine Casualties Jump 75% as Funding for Their Removal Declines
item.media:description: A de-mining operation in Kandahar Province, Afghanistan, in February.
item.description: An annual report on the treaty banning land mines showed that casualties hit 6,461 last year, a sharp rise from 2014 and the highest level in a decade.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: New Quake Tests Resilience, and Faith, in Japan’s Nuclear Plants
item.media:description: Officers at the Fukushima prefectural office gathered data on Tuesday following an earthquake that hit the area.
item.description: The 7.4-magnitude tremor prompted some fearful memories, but the Fukushima Daini and Daiichi power stations seemed to respond well.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: South Korean Leader, Amid Scandal, Approves Intelligence Pact With Japan
item.media:description: Protesters rallying against the intelligence pact, formally the General Security of Military Information Agreement, in Seoul, South Korea, on Tuesday.
item.description: Critics of President Park Geun-hye denounced the cooperation with Korea’s former colonizer, with the main opposition party calling her a “traitorous president.”
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Scenes of Flight From Mosul’s Front Lines
item.media:description: A family fleeing the fighting as oil fields burned in Qayyara, Iraq, this month.
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: The campaign to reclaim Iraq’s second-largest city from the Islamic State has displaced nearly 70,000 Iraqis, and may uproot hundreds of thousands more.
item.dc:creator: SERGEY PONOMAREV and TIM ARANGO
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: A Warlord’s Cuddly Makeover, With a Nod to Donald Trump
item.media:description: Ramzan A. Kadyrov, the leader of Chechnya, attended a mixed martial arts tournament last year in Grozny, Russia. His critics in the West, he said, seek to portray him as “an enemy of the people.”
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: In a reality TV show modeled on “The Apprentice,” Chechnya’s leader, Ramzan A. Kadyrov, is trying to change an image that “I will kill whoever says anything about me.”
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: ISIS Operative Suspected in Paris and Brussels Attacks Is Identified
item.description: The operative, who was previously known only by the nom de guerre Abu Souleymane, is Abdelilah Himich, a 27-year-old from Morocco, the State Department said.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Paris Highway Robbers Target Qatari Sisters in $5.3 Million Heist
item.description: The holdup is the latest in a series of robberies targeting wealthy tourists and famous visitors in and around the French capital.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: The Interpreter: ‘White Nationalism,’ Explained
item.media:description: Stephen K. Bannon in August. President-elect Donald J. Trump’s appointment of Mr. Bannon as his senior counselor and chief West Wing strategist has, more than anything, brought white nationalism to the forefront of conversation.
item.description: Self-proclaimed white nationalists have embraced Donald J. Trump’s victory. Are they the same as white supremacists? Not exactly.
item.dc:creator: AMANDA TAUB

item.title: What in the World: Brazil’s Surfers Lament Demise of Amazon’s Mighty Waves
item.media:description: Jim Davis Rocha de Almeida, 38, looked out at the Amazon River delta in Amapá in October.
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.description: People used to flock to the Araguari River to catch the Pororoca, which once brought waves over five feet high, but surfers last rode it in 2013.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Cyprus Peace Talks End With Each Side Blaming the Other
item.description: Negotiations to end a decades-old division between Greek and Turkish Cypriots broke down Tuesday, and no date was set for a new round of talks.
item.dc:creator: AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE

item.title: Matter: Global Warming Alters Arctic Food Chain, Scientists Say, With Unforeseeable Results
item.media:description: A bloom of algae near Wrangel Island in the Arctic Ocean. The ocean’s levels of algae have rapidly increased.
item.description: The annual production of algae, the base of the food web, increased an estimated 47 percent between 1997 and 2015, and the Arctic Ocean is greening up earlier each year.
item.dc:creator: CARL ZIMMER

item.title: Microcephaly Found in Babies of Zika-Infected Mothers Months After Birth
item.media:description: A 1-year-old child, one of the patients in a new study, showed clear signs of microcephaly, but also had good eye contact.
item.media:credit: van der Linden V, Pessoa A, et al. MMWR: 11.22.2016
item.description: A study published Tuesday found that some babies who did not have unusually small heads when they were born still presented microcephaly months later.
item.dc:creator: PAM BELLUCK
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

item.title: 3 Indian Soldiers Are Killed in Kashmir
item.description: The killings on the border of India and Pakistan occurred amid an unrelenting series of attacks there in recent months.
item.dc:creator: HARI KUMAR and ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Lithuania’s New Prime Minister Pledges to Increase Military Spending
item.media:description: Saulius Skvernelis, center, was named by Lithuania’s Parliament as the new prime minister on Tuesday.
item.description: The new prime minister, Saulius Skvernelis, supports President-elect Donald J. Trump’s call for NATO members to spend more on defense.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD MARTYN-HEMPHILL

item.title: Chinese Museum Mounts an Anselm Kiefer Show, Over the Artist’s Objections
item.media:description: The German artist Anselm Kiefer, shown in 2009, has disavowed a show of his works at a Beijing museum, saying it was organized without his consent.
item.description: The artist said organizers did not obtain his consent for the exhibition, which draws on works held by private collectors.
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN

item.title: U.K. Rejects Donald Trump’s Call for Nigel Farage to Be Made Ambassador
item.description: The American president-elect seems to have gone out of his way once again to embarrass the British government, which is struggling to establish a rapport.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Zika Looms in Asia, Tempered by a Fuller View of Its Dangers
item.media:description: Fumigating against mosquitoes in Bangkok in September. Thailand has had hundreds of cases this year. The country also reported Southeast Asia’s first two cases of Zika-related microcephaly in infants in late September.
item.description: The Zika scare in Latin America has prompted a recent surge in awareness and monitoring of the virus in Asia.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: 15,000 More Public Workers Are Fired in Turkey Crackdown
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey at a ceremony marking the anniversary of the death of Mustafa Kemal Ataturk, the founder of modern Turkey, in Ankara, the capital, this month.
item.description: After a failed coup in July, soldiers and police officers were among the latest cull, accused of links to terrorism or of acting against national security.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND and SAFAK TIMUR
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Lawyers for Egypt's Islamists See High Court as Last Refuge
item.description: Twice this month, Egypt's highest appeals court has struck down harsh sentences against Mohammed Morsi, the elected Islamist president overthrown by the military in 2013, giving some hope to thousands of his supporters, who were jailed or sentenced to death by hasty verdicts following mass trials.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Sinosphere: Daimler Executive Is Removed After Accusations of Insulting Chinese
item.description: Chinese news reports said the German head of a truck and bus division used bigoted language and pepper spray in a parking dispute, setting off a furor on social media.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: U.N.’s Syria Envoy Suggests Donald Trump Has Limited Window to Work With Russia
item.media:description: A view of Aleppo from rebel-held territory. Staffan de Mistura, the United Nations special envoy to Syria, said he feared that the eastern part of the city could be razed before Donald J. Trump is inaugurated.
item.description: The envoy, Staffan de Mistura, said he feared that eastern Aleppo could be obliterated before Donald J. Trump is even inaugurated.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: ‘A Rude Shock’: Indians Describe Life After Narendra Modi’s Currency Ban
item.media:description: Waiting outside a bank in Amritsar, India, to exchange 500- and 1,000-rupee notes.
item.description: We asked Indians to tell us how Mr. Modi’s surprising move, intended to crack down on corruption and tax avoidance, affected them and their families.
item.dc:creator: HANNA INGBER

item.title: Ukraine’s Detention of 2 Servicemen Ignites Dispute With Russia
item.description: Russia said that Ukrainian Security Service operatives had abducted two of its servicemen, who were later described by Kiev as deserters from the Ukrainian Army.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: ISIS Used Chemical Arms at Least 52 Times in Syria and Iraq, Report Says
item.media:description: A cemetery on the outskirts of Gaziantep, Turkey. Grave No. 38487 holds the body of a 4-year-old girl who died of wounds she received when a shell containing sulfur mustard agent hit her home in Marea, Syria.
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: More than one-third of the chemical attacks, which include chlorine and sulfur mustard agents, have come in and around Mosul, the group’s stronghold in Iraq.
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Earthquake Off Fukushima, Japan, Triggers Tsunami
item.media:description: A tsunami wall under construction near the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant in Japan on Tuesday after a strong earthquake. Some residents of Fukushima prefecture were ordered to evacuate early Tuesday after the earthquake, which triggered a tsunami.
item.description: Fears of a nuclear accident were raised as a cooling system in a reactor near the site of the 2011 disaster shut down, but it was restored without incident.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: Alghero Journal: Italy’s Last Bastion of Catalan Language Struggles to Keep It Alive
item.media:description: A street in Alghero, a port city in Sardinia. The traditional insularity of Alghero has helped to preserve Catalan, but the language is fading even here.
item.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times
item.description: The lingering use of Catalan in Alghero, Italy, is a reminder of how Mediterranean cultures have blended for centuries. But the language is fading there today.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: France Detains 7, Saying It Has Thwarted a New Terrorist Attack
item.media:description: French soldiers patrolling in Strasbourg on Monday. Arrests in a suspected terrorist plot were made there and in Marseille.
item.description: After the arrests in Strasbourg and Marseille, investigators were looking into whether the plot involved a “coordinated attack” on multiple targets.
item.dc:creator: BENOÎT MORENNE

item.title: Pope Francis Extends Priests’ Ability to Forgive Abortion
item.description: He made permanent a policy announced last year that allows priests worldwide to grant absolution for an act that the Roman Catholic Church considers a sin.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO and LIAM STACK

item.title: Philippines to Declare Marine Sanctuary in South China Sea
item.media:description: Fishing boats returning in October to Cato, the Philippines, from Scarborough Shoal, a reef in the South China Sea claimed by the Philippines and China.
item.description: President Rodrigo Duterte has proposed a no-fishing zone within Scarborough Shoal, a reef that China also claims — a change that may have little effect.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES

item.title: Why U.K. Is Struggling to Find the Path to ‘Brexit’
item.media:description: The Bank of England in London. Leaders of the European Union are adamant that all members of the single market adhere to the four freedoms: free movement of labor, capital, goods and services.
item.media:credit: Marco Kesseler for The New York Times
item.description: Leaving the European Union might have seemed simple at first, but settling on the details is a matter of philosophical principles as well as economics.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Damascus Diary: A Syrian City Filled With Life, and Hints of Brutal Death
item.description: A visit to the Syrian capital, relatively undamaged by the country’s civil war and outwardly bustling, reveals how war has wounded and warped the city.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Islamic State Again Strikes at Afghan Shiites, Killing at Least 30 in Kabul
item.description: A suicide bombing in Kabul targeted worshipers who were honoring the Islamic ceremony of Arbaeen, and came after another recent assault on a Shiite shrine.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and FAHIM ABED

item.title: Gender Colors Outrage Over Scandal Involving South Korea’s President
item.media:description: Protesters rallied in Seoul, South Korea, on Saturday to call for President Park Geun-hye to step down.
item.description: President Park Geun-hye’s problems have left many South Korean women infuriated and fearful that their patriarchal country will become even more skeptical of female leadership.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Editorial: Myanmar’s War on the Rohingya
item.media:description: A family outside a market destroyed by fire, in a Rohingya village in Myanmar, in October.
item.description: To preserve her reputation as a human rights champion, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi needs to allow an impartial investigation into the violence.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: Don’t Retreat Into Fortress America
item.description: Farsighted leaders put America in a position to lead the world for decades. Will Donald Trump cede that responsibility to Moscow, Beijing or Tehran?
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM S. COHEN and GARY HART
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

item.title: Editorial: A Foolish Power Grab in Congo
item.media:description: President Joseph Kabila, center, of the Democratic Republic of Congo, at a special joint session of parliament on Tuesday.
item.description: President Joseph Kabila’s move to stay in office beyond his term could lead to renewed war in his troubled country.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Where Even Nightmares Are Classified: Psychiatric Care at Guantánamo
item.media:description: A guard tower at a now-empty detention block at Guantánamo Bay. The prison, where nearly 800 men were held over the years, now has 60 detainees.
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Secrecy, mistrust and the shadow of interrogation at the American prison limited doctors’ ability to treat mental illness among detainees.
item.dc:creator: SHERI FINK
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Postcard From the Hajj: A Pilgrim’s Progress: Checking Mecca Off My Bucket List
item.media:description: “Pilgrims surprised me with their warmth.”
item.description: This reporter’s long-dreamed-of journey to explore the heart of Islam revealed surprises, debunked stereotypes and produced one stunning bird video.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Postscript: One Year Later, a Tip About a Border Crossing Pays Off
item.media:description: Laborers transported ammonium nitrate at the crossing from Akcakale, Turkey, into Syria in April 2015. The compound, a common fertilizer, has been used by terrorists to create explosives.
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.description: How New York Times reporting may have made the Middle East just a little bit safer.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and KARAM SHOUMALI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Turkish Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of History
item.media:description: The Turkish town of Hasankeyf will be submerged under 200 feet of water after a hydroelectric dam now under construction is completed.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: A contentious dam project that dates to the 1950s is more than 80 percent complete, and the filling of a reservoir will swamp much of the town of Hasankeyf.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT
